required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Preview Rapid Strep A Test Method Comparison Study
clinical_study.official_title: Preview Rapid Strep A Test Method Comparison Study

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to determine the accuracy of the Preview Rapid Strep A Test compared to a laboratory reference method for Group A Streptococcal infection and to determine the precision of the Preview Rapid Strep A test.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Recruitment rates reduced during non-Strep season

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of Preview Strep A Rapid Test
primary_outcome.description: Determination of Positive Predictive Value and Negative Predictive Value for Preview Strep A

arm_group.description: Any patient presenting with symptoms of pharyngitis Fever Sore throat Swollen lymph nodes in neck Redness of throat/tonsils White/yellow patches on tonsils Not currently on antibiotics

intervention.description: Rapid assay for the detection of type A streptococcal infection of the throat.

study_pop.textblock: Approximately 320 patients to be tested, expecting 50-100 positive for Strep A collected from patients of any age and gender from two CLIA waived or waivable sites. Children will be enrolled in this study due to the high prevalence of Strep A infections in minors and the intention to market this investigational device for use for all ages following FDA clearance.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Any patient presenting with symptoms of pharyngitis
- Fever
- Sore throat
- Swollen lymph nodes in neck
- Redness of throat/tonsils
- White/yellow patches on tonsils
- Not currently on antibiotics
- â‰¥3 years or older
- Ability to read, understand and sign a consent form, in English, or for parent(s) to sign an assent form providing permission to include children under the age of 18.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Currently taking antibiotics
- Previously enrolled in this study
